p: The nearly uniform decrease in site-level richness across the Mojave and the dominant signal of decline in the occupancy suggest a community in the process of collapse. Community or ecosystem collapse is usually the result of multiple causes that create synergistic effects and feedbacks. For example, climate change acted in concert with an emerging disease to threaten global amphibian communities ( 27), with herbivory to threaten Arctic avifauna ( 28), and with a complicated suite of threats to imperil Hawaiian avifauna ( 29). Nevertheless, climate change alone can mediate the collapse of communities ( 5). Whether the collapse of Mojave birds will continue is unknown, although declines of arid-land birds in the BBS may have abated over the past decade ( 19). Nevertheless, populations have not recovered to initial levels, nor have they approached the historic baselines that our surveys revealed.
